Description

This is a vast category, consisting of different genres of (mostly verse) texts that are often recited as parts of other rituals – individual or communal. Most of such prayers are sect-specific, though one also finds some Indian works known throughout all of the different schools of Tibetan Buddhism. Interestingly, these have become the basis for new trans-sectarian rituals.

Note that the Tshig mdzod chen mo defines "prayer" (smon lam) as: "The expression of a mental wish in words" (yid la smon pa tshig gi lam du brjod pa/). The Dung dkar tshig mdzod has: "Praying for the attainment of one’s own desired goal." The Dung dkar tshig mdzod also mentions the Five Prayers: (1) the prayer to generate bodhicitta (sems bskyed pa'i smon lam), (2) the prayer for birth [in a specific place?] (skye ba'i smon lam), (3) the prayer related to objects [?] (spyod yul kyi smon lam), (4) the good prayer (yang dag pa'i smon lam), and (5) the great prayer (smon lam chen mo).

Related Terms

smon tshig, 'dod gsol

Example Texts

  • phyogs bcu dus bzhi sogs smon lam tshan bzhi pa (W22642)
  • gzhi lam ‘bras bu’i smon lam (W22701)
  • smon lam gyi skor (W13700)

Secondary Sources

Beyer, Stephan V. "Worship: Offerings, Praises, and Prayer." In The Cult of Tārā: Magic and Ritual in Tibet, 1-226. Berkeley: University of California Press, 1973.

Lopez, Donald (ed). Religions of Tibet in Practice. Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1997. See section four: "Prayers and Sermons."
